address.streetAddress:
3 Portman Mews South
London W1H 6AY
United Kingdom

review.author: Shaun T.
review.description:
Roti Chai is an absolute favorite. We have a tween and a teen and both love this restaurant. We generally go during the day where crowds are lesser, waiting 10-15 minutes if that. 
The "street food" menu is what we like on the upper floor, and consists of big plates and tapas style small plates. 
We mix it up every time and are never disappointed. 
This is a fantastic stop in London.

review.author: Adnan K.
review.description:
Amazing food upstairs.incredible kulfi and chicken lollipops. 
Pani puri amazing
Chat papri
Lychee coconut and guava drink

review.author: Olivier B.
review.description:
This is a good place to eat! Its loud its crowded:) but its smell good from 10 milles away. I like the street food so i sat upstairs! Downstairs its more for a formal dinner.
5 minutes after we order the first appetizer arrive and the flavour is great and wonderful. 
If you dont like spicy food then its just not your place. If you love indian food its just great. 
ITS GOODDDDDDDDD

review.author: Wesley S.
review.description: Excellent food and service. My wife and I stopped in and sampled a bunch of items in the upstairs restaurants. Everything was really good and seasoned well.

review.author: Annie M.
review.description:
Roti Chai is located on Portman Mew S and near Portman St in Marylebone, London.
We found Roti Chai highly rated in Yelp and we would like to check it out.  We came here for dinner and they're not busy at all.  The hostess asked us would like to try street kitchen or dinning room.  We hesitated the different and checked the menu pretty the same dishes.  
We prefered to have Indian Tapas and we could ordered a bit more. 
Garlic Naan - it's fresh made, soft and fluffy. 
Vegetable Samosa - it's good but not great.
Macher Jhol - fish curry just ok and not flavourful. 
Railway Lamb Curry - it's medicore and curry wasn't rich.
Overall, lacking food presentation and not authentic dish but the service was excellent.

review.author: Vinayak H.
review.description: This restaurant is not good for families . When we went we had a long line . But this restaurant does not even have basics of taking people's names in a list . They prioritize two people . We had to wait more than an hour even though they said the wait would be 45 minutes because they send people who came even 30 minutes later than us they were just two people . The restaurant is full of two sets that can be combined but they don't do it . So if you are more than two people especially 3 or 5 don't waste your time waiting here .

review.author: mary r.
review.description: Simply lovely Indian small plates. Super tired after 2 weeks of travel and walking into the place the smell was intoxicating. We were greeted warmly and had great service and food. Will definitely be back on our next trip to London

review.author: Shirley G.
review.description: Very rude host. Have had much better Indian food. Once was enough. Twice we arrived before closing and were told not seating anymore. Finally got in and not impressed.

review.author: Kathleen Y.
review.description:
Great meal with an interesting atmosphere. You can choose upstairs for street food and downstairs for fine dining. We chose downstairs and had a few small dishes all very good. Next time we will try the upstairs menu.
Flavors reminded me of my time in India.

review.author: Lisa D.
review.description: Oh Roti Chai how I've missed you!!!  Roti Chai isalways our first stop when visiting London and one of our favorite Indian restaurants in the city!  We have always ate at the dining room downstairs.  We love the vibrant and cozy atmosphere.  On this particular trip we ordered: Tandoori chicken, chili garlic prawns, crab and fish cakes, saffron chicken tikka, curry leaf potatoes and butter chicken.  Everything  (as always) is fantastic!!  See you next time!

review.author: Laura S.
review.description:
The place tricks you into thinking you're going to get the same good in the upstairs restaurant. 
If you want the authentic stuff, they have it in the bottom floor. Unfortunately, we waited an hour for nothing in the street food menu. Came here from the states because of the reviews.
Going to Dishoom. They have the same menu throughout and worth the wait.
They even charge service charge on drinks we got earlier. We didn't end up eating there.

review.author: Eakan G.
review.description:
Came here for a reserved dinner. Started with some refreshing drinks, virgin cocktails actually: kovalam beach, lemonade elderflower drink. Then had the fantastic chilli garlic prawns and saffron chicken Tikka. Absolute delight!
Looking to order Raan e Baluchi, a slow cooked Welsh lamb shoulder shank with cumin tandoori masala with some roti selection.

review.author: Vivian G.
review.description:
DELICIOUS!! After a day of touring around London, this meal hit the spot. So they have an upstairs level for Indian street food and a downstairs level for dining in. We dined in and was satisfied with the service and the food. Must try if you are in London!!!
P.S. the main dish doesn't come with rice.

review.author: Helene V.
review.description:
Incredible Indian Restaurant. 
Food is perfect and the place is really nice. 
To share a diner with friends on a Friday night,it's perfect :)

review.author: Juliana M.
review.description:
I had just got back from India and I almost couldn't see another Indian dish to save my life but my friends insisted! Soooo good. This fusion place combines the best flavors of India with an airy lightness in the dishes that is a superb compliment. The vibe was decked out cool and the staff was very friendly. 
Fav eats - chicken lollipops vs their green sauce is a tight call, chili paneer is feisty and the samosa chat was delish 
Overall, this place is brilliant

review.author: Danesh I.
review.description:
In a city with no shortage of good food, Roti Chai is definitely a runt of the litter. The branding and decor are cool, but there's not a whole lot of depth below the surface. 
The food is rather bland for Indian food, and the whole street food shtick has been become rather tired and trite. This must be the universe's way of saying "beta, don't waste your shillings on such mediocre khaana when you can eat your ammi's cooking and buy her a gift with the money instead": point taken universe! 
The cocktails are actually fantastic here, and the few my brother and I tried were delicious, and reasonably priced...the food on the other hand was uninspired. The agni "fire" wings were fatty and chewy and as far them being "dangerously hot and spicy" per our waitress...mah, me thinks not. The English concept of "spicy" is laughable and the general lack of "mirch" left most dishes lacking in any sort of real flavor. 
I'd stop in for drinks and maybe a samosa...beyond that, just go to Dishoom!

review.author: Meike B.
review.description: A bit of a secret tip this, and I'll be eternally grateful to the friend who suggested a quick curry at the end of an evening. We were amongst the last people in and food was delivered superfast. With trains to catch we were after a quick fix rather than romantic atmosphere making this a winner on all counts.

review.author: Jin K.
review.description:
Wanted late night Indian while in London so we popped into the Street Kitchen part of the restaurant and couldn't have been more pleased. The environment was lively and busy, but not too distracting, service was prompt, and food was amaaaaazing. We loved all our dishes -- So much flavor, spice, and depth! My husband and I tried an assortment of small dishes including the Hakka Chili Paneer salad, which was honestly, my favorite dish. It came with deep fried tofu cubes, green pepper slivers, tomatoes, and fresh chili, all tossed in a savory dressing over lettuce. The chili was fierce, which gave the warm salad a fun kick. 
Highly recommend going with a group and ordering all the things. Great small plates that make it easy to share, taste, and order more!

review.author: Vijay B.
review.description:
Pedestrian food and terrible service
This location has two restaurants. The restaurant on the lower level is a formal sit down and upstairs is a casual first come first serve location. Front desk is understaffed and rude. They consistently seated others ahead of us in the upstairs location. After they seated us, the waiter forgot our order. We were waiting for 30 mins and when we followed up they told us we need to hurry up and order. When I told them, incredulously, that I have ordered and am waiting, the person went away from only to come back annoyed at us and took our order again. Not a word of apology. Food's not worth the hassle. Never going back.

review.author: Terry C.
review.description:
As a vegan I'm a pretty big fan of Indian food. This place is pretty decent. Usually has a lot of people eating around here. If you like Indian food and spicy food, then this is the place for you. Otherwise, it might be hard to adjust haha.
Lots of good veggie dishes and I love their guava drink

address.streetAddress:
3 Portman Mews South
London W1H 6AY
United Kingdom

review.author: Melanie O.
review.description: Delicious surprise.   We stopped to refuel after shopping and were thrilled with the tapas.  We had several chicken dishes,soma as, and rose lemonade.  Definitely would come here again for dinner next time.

review.author: Seo Young M.
review.description: Ate downstairs at the dining area. Must be a little bit more expensive than upstairs but it was worth it! The specials menu were amazing. The lamb special that was cooked for 16 hours was so tender and the butter chicken was one of the best I ever had!

review.author: Adela K.
review.description:
Not bad. It's not too traditional, a bit of a modern twist to the snacks and chaat. Overall everything we ordered was good. 
If I come back then I would definitely eat downstairs at the restaurant. They have a cool bar area that you can sit at while you wait... drinks are good too.

review.author: Lucia L.
review.description:
Love this place for casual dinners in the street kitchen upstairs. Everything I've tried has been delicious - from the refreshing papri chaat to the creamy kulfis - its all spot on. The naan sampler is great with anything, especially the curries, such as the pulusu chicken curry.
The only thing is that service can be a bit slow - a bartender had noticed that we weren't being serviced and had to alert a waitress to get to us. But besides that, I'll be back to try more of their contemporary take on Indian food!

review.author: Amanda M.
review.description:
We brought our friends from out of town here and it was so much fun to try everything. I've learned that you need to make reservations and if you don't have one, there's a pub right next door where you can grab a beer while you wait! 
One of my favourite things here is chill paneer- AMAZZZZZING! It's spicy but the cheese is a nice balance and the texture of the cheese is chewy but so good. I don't really know how to describe paneer in a pleasing way but whatever it's amazing and you should try it. 
I also really loved the Macher jhol- excellent flavour and just enough spice. I still have yet to try their burger or sandwich, but I'm sure I'll be back sometime.

review.author: Alicia C.
review.description: Stellar experience! We ate in the dining room and it was phenomenal. Beautiful ambiance, warm, cozy and welcoming. All of the food was flavored impeccably. Even the garlic naan felt like the garlic was intentional and not just an after thought. So rich! The paneer pakora came with a brilliantly spicy sauce. It was like Indian mozzarella sticks in the very best way possible. Not diminishing any of the quality, just want to give a little context. My butter chicken was scrape your bowl clean good. Finish every drop good. You better order more naan good. The chicken was juicy and tender. Even my peppermint and fennel tea was great. What a great compliment to my meal. Highly recommend!

review.author: Kristen Carlson D.
review.description: Really good Indian Food. The spice is mild but they can turn up the heat if asked.  There is an upstairs and downstairs.  Upstairs is Indian fusion soul food and informal.  Downstairs is traditional. We are downstairs and all I can say is Yum!   The servers were helpful in picking wine and recommending dishes.  So good. Will be eating here again!

review.author: Kadee W.
review.description: So yummy! We took the recommendations based on another yelp review and we weren't disappointed. We ate the more casual street food and loved every bite. The cocktails were super yummy too! Next time we will try the formal dining room. No wonder this place is packed!

review.author: Dan C.
review.description:
I came here for lunch a little over a week ago.  I will get right to it.  The food is bonkers.  Roti has 2 dining rooms - a street kitchen and a dining room downstairs.   I ate in the street kitchen.  I guess the street kitchen is focused on street-style food.  We ordered tons of stuff as they recommend you order an appetizer and a main.  I got the chicken wings and a lamb kebab burger.  The food was ridiculously good.  I went there with a couple of foodies and they were "oooh...ahhhh" over everything.   
The service was pretty poor, we were constantly waving the staff people down like stranded people on an island wave down a passing ship. That said the food more than made up for it.  I can brag all day about the food in New York, blah, blah, blah, but there is nothing like Roti Chai.  Go to Roti Chai.  You'll love it.

review.author: Morgan J.
review.description:
I LOVED the Hakka Chili Paneer. The paneer had the best flavor and texture I have ever experienced. The dish itself was a new way of eating paneer for me, a warm salad. I would LOVE to know how they prepared the paneer! Also ate the Gobi Manchurian, which was also good.
I went back a second time because I was so thrilled with my first visit. This time the service was not very good and the Hakka Chili Paneer was WAY more spicy. I did speak with the host and he said he would speak with the kitchen. He was very receptive of feedback.
The Orange Blush drink was also a very good virgin drink option, super fruity. The second time I went back I asked for it with less ice, because the first time it was about 80% ice and I finished it in two gulps.

review.author: Brian S.
review.description: Came to London on a family vacation. While shopping around the Oxford Circle area we all got hungry so I looked up somewhere close on yelp and decided to check this place out. What a gem! It's located right around the corner from Selfridges. There's seating upstairs (smaller plates) and a full restaurant down stairs. We elected for the full restaurant and couldn't have been happier. Food is excellent and the staff is very friendly and attentive. We enjoyed it so much that we came back again a few days later and tried upstairs this time around. The menu is slightly different with smaller plates but everything is just as good and didn't disappoint.  Will definitely be stopping by again the next time we're back in town!

review.author: Analyn A.
review.description:
Can't be in London and not have Indian food.   I had wanted to eat her based on all the YELP reviews.   What I didn't realize was that they have two area,  one where the street food is served and the off a more upscale restaurant.  Tip, if you make reservations it'll be for the upscale part.   Not comparing as the food w had was amazing! 
Both areas are decorated slightly different,  but downstairs - the upscale portion is very nice and modern.  It gave me the feel of being on a train with overhead lugged,  etc.  But in the premium seating,  LOL.
We love every dish!   The flavors and spice were spot on.  Would definitely come here again!

review.author: Kitt P.
review.description:
Is It possible to stay in London and not have Indian food? I don't think so.... 
Arrived for a late night dinner and there was a bit of a queue both downstairs (dining room) and upstairs (Street kitchen). The hostess told us that we could have a table at the street kitchen in about half an hour and offered us to wait at the bar and so we did.
Had a bellini while waiting and my boyfriend had a mango caipirinha and both was excellent. When our table was ready the hostess came and took our drinks and accompanied us to the table. 
It's recommended to pick 1-2 sidedishes and 1 maindish, but since we we're kindda full from our afternoon tea earlier this day we decided to choose 1 sidedish and 1 main each.
Had the chicken lollipops which I highly recommend for sidedish and also the chicken samosas - really tasty. 
Both had the pulusu chicken for main course and I loved it... My boyfriend found it a bit to spicy though. It was served with rice. We ordered mango fizz and orange blush to drink and both was yummy. 
Quick and polite service.

review.author: Karishma P.
review.description:
I'd bookmarked this place awhile ago and had been waiting for an opportunity to go here. Shopping with my brother on Oxford street today, provided that opportunity.
We needed a quick lunch before another appointment, so I couldnt relax and enjoy the chaat - paani puri / bhelpuri etc. We opted straight for the protein dishes.
The chicken lollipops were good, but standard fare. The agni fire wings, were mind blowingly spicy in a good way. But be warned - this is only for chilli addicts. You can't handle the spice otherwise.
The manchurian chicken was a let down, especially as it was served with a very thin sauce and plain rice (Its a very Indian Chinese dish, served almost dry and with fried rice) the taste was good, but it was a disappointment purely because of its name. They should call it sweet and sour chicken or something.
Brother enjoyed his bun kebab.
However, the only thing that really stood out for me was the hot chocolate with its lovely cinnamon notes.
Service was efficient and friendly. I might return to check out the chaat items, but for a meal, I'd rather go elsewhere.

review.author: Grant N.
review.description: The service was terrible and the food was okay. The waitress brought our bread 10 minutes after we had finished all of our other courses. The samosas we ordered still never arrived and after telling her again she said "okay Ill do you a favor and not bring them". They throw out ALL food after without letting you take it home!! How is that even a valid option-- What about food waste? Overall a really frustrating experience that could have been diverted by better service and a disclaimer when ordering extra food, with intention to bring some home, that they toss it in the rubbish like their service.

review.author: Kalyan K.
review.description:
Really nice food, true to Indian tastebuds. No watered down versions of indian dishes
Very nice chaat and pain poori, hard to get them as good even in India

review.author: James B.
review.description:
This is a refreshing twist on Indochinese street food.
A regular place we like to visit once or twice a month. There is no table booking so be prepared to queue if you are going at busy dinning times. If you prefer something a little more formal, they have a dinning room downstairs that caters a different menu (more a la carte).
A favourite in the heart of London

review.author: Prerna M.
review.description: After reading reviews, I was hoping that this place will be good but I was disappointed. I ordered hakka chilli paneer for starters and idli sambhar for main course, along with mohito. Hakka chilli was good which raised my expectations. But idli sambhar just fell flat. The salt was less in sambhar, idli was not at all fluffy and seemed cakey. Mohito was terrible. Decor is wanna be Indian.

review.author: Mo M.
review.description:
We had the street food upstairs. The food is tasty but the portions are really small. You would need to order atleast 2-3 dishes to have a full stomach. They also need to add more on their menu.
Also, the place is not particularly kid friendly. If you have really small kids, i would not recommend this place to you.

review.author: Sam C.
review.description:
Not far from the shopping of Oxford Street hides this little gem. I glanced at the menu outside and it's a bit confusing. They have two dining areas. Downstairs for a slightly more expensive menu. 
I ate on the main floor, street kitchen menu - casual dining. The prices are very fair for London standards. The chicken lollipops are outstanding! Almost every table around me ordered them as well.
I had the lamb curry with rice instead. Perfectly spiced and there is nice heat to it! Portion size may be a bit small if you're hungry and didn't order an appetizer. 
The dessert, almond & saffron phirni, was great ending to the meal. Lightly sweetened, great for not-a-sweet-tooth person. 
The only reason for 4* is the 12.5% mandatory service charge, no matter the party size. They have plenty of staff walking around and very pleasant to talk to but I am not a fan of mandatory service charges.

address.streetAddress:
3 Portman Mews South
London W1H 6AY
United Kingdom

review.author: Elizabeth W.
review.description:
Authentic, delicious, friendly staff, good service and reasonably priced!
Can't wait to go back.
Loved this place - recommend the paneer starter (but very very spicy) and the duck keema which comes with a buttery roll.
Only let down was the choice of beers

review.author: Uma J.
review.description: Excellent food, great service. Get the pomegranate martini and the chicken lolllipops!!

review.author: Ameya B.
review.description:
Okay this was the best Indian food I've had so far in London. Nice place, good vibe and excellent food! Went here as a group of 3, and at around 8:15 pm; they had a 5 minute wait for the Street Kitchen. They also have a fine dining area, which we weren't really interested in.
We ordered some Chilli Paneer for the table, which came after our entrees -- but it was good in a way. The Chilli Paneer's spice level is nuclear. I usually enjoy spicy food, but even I couldn't handle their spice level towards the end.
For main course, I tried their Macher Jhol. It was absolutely delicious! I wasn't too impressed with the portion size. At £8.50, I expected a bit more.. but whatever portion was served was absolutely yumm!
Definitely recommend this if you are into spicy and delicious food!

review.author: Alan S.
review.description: I had heard that London has the best Indian food in the world. I am fortunate to live near a local Indian restaurant that is outstanding. I have had Indian food in other countries as well. Here in London, I don't think anything could be better than Roti Chai. I had prawns in a delicious tangy and sweet sauce and my wife had a lamb dish. The lamb was tender and fell off the bone. We also ordered the Nan with a hint of orange zest. I love Nan in any form and this did not disappoint. We also order drinks an dessert. I had a    Caipirinha that was muddled with Mango and lime, perfect. If in London, in the Mayfair section, don't miss out on this place.

review.author: Wendy L.
review.description:
Roti Chai is separated into a ground floor street kitchen, serving modern Indian street food specifically made for sharing and a dining room downstairs, serving a more formal a la carte menu. As we fined in on ground floor we can only give our review on the Street Kitchen.
So the ground floor was an informal dining scene resembling much like a upmarket canteen with upscaled retro Indian food labels as posters. It had a nice buzzing atmosphere with a good amount of sunlight coming in giving the place a warm vibe accentuated by the warm glow lighting. The other diners in the restaurant were mostly South Asian which must say a lot about the authenticity of flavours. 
Plenty of staff although nearly always occupied which meant it was hard to get their attention at times. However food was delivered quickly and service was friendly and welcoming.
Aloo papri chaat
A sensational dish using a wide combination of textures and flavours making each bite as exciting as the first bite. Wheat crisp bases gave it that crunchy texture and held onto it throughout and this was contrasted by the fluffy potatoes and chickpeas soaking up the flavours. Pomegranates gave it a burst of sweetness against the silky plain yogurt whilst basil added a nice refreshing aromas against the lovely hot and tangy chutney and mild sweet spices 
Dhokla
I was very surprised how moist and airy this steamed chickpea cake was. They must have been finely grounded to produce such a spongy smooth texture. It was subtly sweet with a nice light drizzle of tangy chutney on top to lift its flavour 
Pani puri 
This dish was quite forgettable and didn't offer much to the palate. The semolina shells were very nice and delicately crisp but with only a bit of potato and only one chickpea in there, you could barely taste it. The tamarind water was too overpowering, even with just a little bit it masked all flavours with its strong sour notes 
Bun kebab
I did really enjoy how fragrant and aromatic the lamb patty was with the addition of spices and herbs in there giving it a good punch of flavour. However the bun was way too thick and dense to allow the flavours to project through, either that or the patty was too thin. A lovely side of tangy chutney to help it along with flavour but still a wasted patty 
Bombay bhel puri 
A dish that always gets me coming back to this restaurant. A fantastic mixture of crunchy wheat crisp, puffed rice, spicy red onions mixed in with little cubes of fluffy potatoes, chickpeas and more. It created such a moreish bite with the variation of textures and all in a refreshing tangy tamarind spice.
Idli Sambar
The most important thing about this dish is getting the steamed rice cakes right and achieving that sponginess to soak up the curry and they got it spot on. They were so light and fluffy that were a joy to eat it with the lovely mild vegetable curry that had its own lovely complex savoury flavours. Quite a thin consistency which made it easier to absorb by the rice cakes. 
Aloo gobi
A side of cauliflower and potatoes. This dish was fantastic and all very well spiced in a thick curry paste making it the most spiciest dish we ordered. It also had depth and complexity in its flavours. The potatoes were incredibly fluffy and with skin on giving it that nice contrast in texture. Cauliflowers were cooked till soft so blended in well with the onions that helps added a nice sweetness to the dish 
Almond and saffron phirni
Resembling somewhere in between of semolina and panna cotta with its slight graininess and jelly like texture and milkiness. It was incredible and I love the saffron in there giving it that lovely sweet spiced aroma to it. Almonds finished it nicely by offering it a nice nutty crunch.
I do love Roti Chai Street Kitchen. It's a no reservation place unless you come in a large group. But food is served so quickly that people leave in no time so you don't tend to have to wait long. Dishes have room for improvement but the combinations of flavours and textures in some of the dishes just blows me away and keeps me from coming back. They're all so visually stunning too. Prices are very reasonable and it's great that they come in small sizes so you can order a few or lots to share. Great for birthday celebrations too and for those who are worried about spice levels, most of the dishes we ordered were very mild apart from the Aloo Gobi.

review.author: Khalifa S.
review.description: Hi.. really amazing restaurant .. small dishes with many delicious different flavours .. I will visit it again for sure next time I am in London

review.author: Jason G.
review.description: Came here 2 years ago for our honeymoon and just had it tonight...still amazing! FYI, the wings are super spicy but full of flavor!

review.author: Jennifer S.
review.description: Having heard of the reputation of Indian food in London I had great expectations but was a bit disappointed.  This restaurant is in the Marble Arch neighborhood.  There's two different floors and the first floor seems to be more casual while the bottom floor is more formal, for walk in the wait was only around 10 minutes. I got the lamb curry dish and the lamb was very dry and the sauce not very flavorful.  The chapati that came with it was very dry as well and I should have opted for rice instead.  I tried the chicken curry dish which was much better.

review.author: Chris W.
review.description:
Stopped in for lunch at about 1:45, place was still packed. Had a short wait; host had me order my beer and I was seated before it arrived. 
Ordered the chicken lollipop for a starter. Very good, hot, not greasy tasting. 
Then had the railway lamb curry (with potato). It came with two chopati (like a burrito) so I skipped the naan. (Garlic naan wasn't available, maybe just in the dining room? Another reviewer noted it was very good)
It was very good; I felt I couldn't really taste lamb however. 
It didn't appear that the basement dining room was open, there wasn't anyone down there when I used the toilet (lavatories) after eating. 
Net-net I would go back. The fact that it was packed with all the choices around (Selfridges & Marks and Spencer food courts, for example) attest to its popularity.

review.author: Saad S.
review.description:
My number 1 restaurant ..
All the menu is amazing special biryanis and samosas try the chicken burger as well

review.author: G L.
review.description: My cousin who lives in London told us about this place - it was awesome!  We were visiting from Chicago.  Very crowded but their service was impeccable - thank you to Sarah.  We ordered chicken lollipops, pani puri, bhel puri, aloo chaat papdi, railway lamb curry and Manchurian chicken and it was all amazing.  The lychee martinis were perfect.  We would highly recommend this place if you are in London.

review.author: Sampad D.
review.description:
Good indian food. It has two options for seating - 1) Serving street food 2) Full family size restaurant.
We tried the street food one. the food was just awesome.
We got chicken lolipop. It was ok.We also ordered railway lamb curry and macher jhol. Both of them were awesome.Will highly recommend these !
The ambiance is ok and service is also fine.Will highly recommend this place !

review.author: Cindy P.
review.description: I think everyone needs to eat upstairs first and then try the restaurant downstairs.  We were simply speechless after eating our entrees. It was simply that good. The service was excellent. They were there for our every need. We started this awesome meal with two small plates...Gilafi Seekh Kebab and Chicken 65. Both of these dishes were spicey hot and we were thankful for the beer and water.  Our entrees were on the milder side, but they were packed full of flavor. I got Malaba Mooli Prawns and my husband got Malai Methi Paneer. We also got some garlic butter roti. The shrimp was cooked to perfection. I have no idea what was in that sauce, but I literally could have licked the bowl. The Paneer was vegetarian. It was made with cheese chunks. Again, you could lick the bowl. The Roti bread was perfect for licking the bowl and looking polite. This was by far my favorite meal of the trip. You know I will be back to this restaurant.

review.author: Devin A.
review.description: REALLY TASTY!  We had the small plates upstairs and were able to taste a lot of different dishes and all of them were amazing.  The service was also excellent!  I highly recommend Roti Chai.

review.author: S K.
review.description:
very trendy and the food was excellent.  We tried several items and the Lamb curry as well as the chicken curry were excellent.  order the Lamb with rice instead of the roti it comes with.  
also the pani puri is delicious just delicious.   its very loud so do nit go for business meetings but definitely a place to go with friends.  would not recommend for kids.   too busy
i loved the papaya melon juice as well.

review.author: Lauren V.
review.description:
For the prices I cannot believe how poor the service was and that the drinks were served warm and the food cold.
We sat in the street kitchen section and all chaats were £4+ (Which makes one wonder when this up market street food trend will just implode).
I asked what the most popular small plates were, which is how I ended up with the chicken samosas (piled with yoghurt, pomegranate, spicy sauce and crispy bits) and the chicken lollipops. The samosas were lukewarm under their cup of cold yoghurt but still crunchy (and tasty, I really liked them). The lollipops were pretty boring to me but the husband loved them.
I ordered a prosecco cocktail that came out instantly, which would explain why it was flat and warm. I sent that shit back because come on. Really? The samosas had also come out right after I ordered them, so I guess they just make a bunch of food and drinks at once and then send it out when it's ordered? Lame.
My husband ordered the railway lamb curry, which was teeny tiny for the £9 price tag. Kept having to flag down the servers, even though it wasn't too busy (we were heading off to a show so had to leave at a specific time).
Bummed out as I had been wanting to try this place out since they attended a yelp event and served a fantastic (hot) chaat.

review.author: Hans D.
review.description: Stept in for a quick lunch. Clean, not too shabby. Wouldn't come pver from the other part of town for this but it's good for its price.

review.author: Julianne W.
review.description: Best Indian food I've ever had. Ever. The lamb was incredible, the naan flavors are delicious and the atmosphere is great. If you eat Indian in one place in London eat it here.

review.author: Ocean S.
review.description: We found Roti Chai through Yelp. We tried the taste manual with cocktail. I cannot wait till I get out of the restaurant to give the restaurant a 5-Star rating. For £35/person, my husband had a martini and I had a mojito. We thought we chose one of the 3 options from the starters and one of the four main courses. But NO - we got ALL OF THE 3 and 4, plus lentil soup and desert. Every single item on the manual is delicious and the plating is beautiful. The spices are so tasty but not overwhelming, that you can still taste the freshness of the meat and vegetable. I am now waiting for my desert and I am sure that they will be as good. Thumbs up. It is by far the best Indian food I have ever had. We will definitely return.

review.author: Mark T.
review.description:
6 stars.
the food here is really amazing.
recommended: chili prawns & lamb kebab (both are appetizers), garlic naan, butter chicken.
highly recommended: the CHEESECAKE.
this place will not disappoint!

address.streetAddress:
3 Portman Mews South
London W1H 6AY
United Kingdom

review.author: Dipan P.
review.description: We stopped in last year during our trip to UK...recommend by family as a place to not miss...went with high expectations and  were blown away by the quality and taste of the dishes.  Unique takes on classic dishes...steer food elevated to fine dinning quality and beyond.  Our kids were loving the place to. We rave to all our friends visiting and they all thank us afterwards....definitely crowded so if you can sneak in a little before the crowds show up you will be much happier....happy eating!!!

review.author: Kimmi D.
review.description: It was a little hidden jem for my friends and I that we stumble onto. We love the modern hip decor and the service was good as well. We liked the food and drinks :)

review.author: Megan B.
review.description:
This place really has some incredible food. And the small plates versus main allows you to trial and share some really fabulous dishes. The most popular one we saw was the warm paneer salad on every table. It was really quite spicy and warm lettuce could throw you off, but definitely worth consuming. I could have eaten one whole one by myself, but then I wouldn't have been able to taste anything else due to the spice level. 
Our table also ordered the railroad lamb curry stew, which was quite good and the "burrito" like wrap for it did not quite hold in all the stew. Would possibly recommend ordering a side of rice to eat with this. And the chicken burger, but I don't remember its name off the top of my head. This was more than enough food for 2 people for lunch, though everything was so good it wouldn't hurt to order more just to try everything on the menu. Or bring a big group here so you can split everything.

review.author: Saminda W.
review.description:
What a fantastic experience from start to finish.  
We descended into the downstairs to some of the most elegant modern decor, complemented by equally polished service.  The surroundings and attentiveness was pitch perfect.
Everything we tried from the menu was delicious but the standouts were the paneer and pepper kabobs dusted with chili and from our entrees, the palak paneer, tarka dahl and chicken tikka were absolutely heavenly.  Our cocktails could have been made a little less sweeter but otherwise, the meal was perfect.  We will be returning here before returning home!

review.author: Charles J.
review.description: Come here a couple of times. Like, but not love it. Good food, OK vibe, decent night out, but nothing too special.

review.author: Paula M.
review.description:
So many good reviews already for this restaurant and once you are there, it is easy to see why.  Read them and I agree with them all!
The food is so flavoursome and good portions (I've only been here for lunch).  Service has always been good with the serving staff knowledgable in what they are serving.  You can easily come her for lunch, have a good meal and be back in the office within the hour or there abouts which, is always a bonus.
Not so great on desserts but the starters and the mains are soooo nice it doesn't really matter.  So far, I've not eaten anything here that I did not like will be back and back again.

review.author: Gabriela W.
review.description:
Best Indian food I've ever had. No lie. 
Downstairs dining area: 
I'm veggie, and was surprised to see so many options on the menu. I started out with the palak papri chaat. Excellent. My husband and I shared the Schezwan chilli paneer. Seriously, hold me down. Bada**. I then had the palak paneer and tarka daal, accompanied by the roti and naan plate. Wow, the paneer melted in my mouth, the palak was of the gods, and the daal was unique, and tasted like the most epic buttery daal goodness I've ever had. Broke my taste buds. Rico. Rico. Rico.
The service was excellent. The waiter and manager were both very present, without being overbearing. 
Def going back!
Update:
2 days later we went back to try the Indian street food (upstairs). Def underwhelming. They were slammed, and maybe that affected preparation/service. I wouldn't go back for the street food, but would for sure go back to the dining room food.

review.author: Eleanor W.
review.description: Not real Indian food. I lived in New York and other states and never had Bad Indian food. This food was nasty. London you need to learn better

review.author: Brigitte F.
review.description: I actually ate downstairs in the restaurant. Food was  really good. Garlic naan was amazing. Upstairs is more fast food style with different menu. Was packed so I would suggest reservations if avail as an option. Giving 4 rather than 5 due to wait staff. Brought out entree before starters (and not at same time as my friends entree so it got cold while I waited for hers to come as it is rude to eat in front of someone whom is hungry).

review.author: David E.
review.description: Good food, great presentation and a creative menu. Definitely worth a visit for those dealing with a craving for Indian food.

review.author: Vera W.
review.description:
The service here is terrible! It's too bad because the food is actually decent. The pani puri and chicken lollipops were flavorful. The chicken curry and cauliflower veg dish were okay. Not super authentic but good enough for the price. 
I wish I could give them 3.5 stars. Good enough for quick Indian food, but do not expect anything from the service. It was some of the worst I've ever experienced.
If you want fantastic Indian, I would still go to Dishoom.

review.author: Ken D.
review.description: Very nice. Appreciated the space usage and the decor. Waited a short time for a table, but the staff was very helpful w/a cocktail. Food came fast, was tastie and delicious. Portions were spot on, shared w/college. Happenings spot. Go for a great night. Serve lunch too.

review.author: Jory S.
review.description:
We ate on their lower level and found that the food was fantastic, the service was warm and engaging, and the location was convenient!  Very well done in every regards.  Our server was charming and attentive, the food was so good and they offered an interesting menu with some unexpected items.  
Happy to refer friends and family here!

review.author: Merijn H.
review.description:
If the place is full with a lot of Indians it must be a good place right? This place is full with both Indian business men and Indian families, so expect a noisy crowd but also great food.
I feel lucky to love Indian food and even more lucky to have found this place. I have not yet tried the second floor dining restaurant but I do love the ground floor street food restaurant. It's a light, clean and open, modern interior with some Indian street signs. 
The chai is tasty and has real spices, the chilli paneer is nicely spicy (really great but actually quite spicy) and comes with a lot of vegetables (a bit more paneer would have been great), the pani puri is a fun chaat dish and often not advisable to have in India because of the water used but here it's just great.
The Andra Pradesh chicken curry is a great spicy juicy curry and made me almost overeat myself, just like I use to do in India ;-)
The food is very affordable as well, great value!

review.author: Priyanka R.
review.description:
A Indian New Yorker has Indian food in London. 
The YELP community very rarely leads me astray, and although they were a little bit below the mark, Roti Chai was still a decent food option. To note, I am sure there are plenty other fantastic Indian spots in this city, that this wouldn't be my first pick going forward. But if you are in the neighborhood and want quick food and service this would probably be your best bet. Let's break it down shall we?
3 friends go to Roti Chai and share some Indian dishes Tapas style, and here's what we thought!
STREET SECTION:
1. Aloo Papri Chaat (4.8GBP) - The papri (circular fried bread base was crispy, but not fresh), the aloo (potato) was well made, and the toppings were tasty, but not fresh again. It was decent, and edible, but not exciting or by any means the best papri chaat I've had. Decently priced for the portion. Rating = 3/5
2. Chicken Lollipops (5.5GBP) - Good texture, taste, although could have used more flavor, spice, and seasoning. But still delicious, and one of the better dishes we had, good price for the portion. Rating = 4/5
3. Agni 'Fire' Wings (5.9GBP) - Well made, although I thought the chicken could have been cook a tad more. The accompanying sauces were good, and the wings were indeed spicy. I will have to say, they were not "Indian spicy" but still created some heat and were well "sauced." Again, good portion for the price. Rating = 4/5
4. Hakka Chilli Paneer (5.5GBP) - My favorite dish, as the quality of each paneer was perfection. Perfectly seasoned and flavored. The paneer was also cooked to perfection and tasted more fresh than 1, 2 and 3 (above). My one qualm with this dish was there was very little paneer, and vegetables took up most of the dish which isn't what you are paying for. Quality = 4/5, Quantity = 3/5, Rating = 3.5/5.
ROAD & RAIL:
1. Gobi Manchurian (7.2GBP) - This dish was all that was wrong. The gobi Manchurian was slightly stale, the sauce ruined the gobi, and gobi itself tasted like it was undercooked, the cauliflower (gobi) was still a bit hard and the dish just 100% made me wish I could have my 7GBP back, this dish really ruined the meal for me. Rating = 0/5. Sorry for the awful rating, but do not order this dish. 
2. Railway Lamb Curry (8.5GBP) - The Lamb was decently cooked, but could have been softer. Whenever I've had lamb curry, it has melted in my mouth, so this was a bit of a disappointment. It was not really spicy, but there was a bit of flavor, could have been cooked longer, and with more flavor. Overall probably would not order it again, but it was decent. Rating = 3/5.
SWEET:
1. Pistachio Kulfi (2.9GBP) - Although I love Kulfi, and it was good, it tasted like it was a "packaged kulfi" and they just unwrapped it an put it in a glass for me to eat. Still delicious, but still not the kind of fresh made Kulfi I was expecting. Rating 4/5. 
WiFi was good at the restaurant, and the service was solid (sometimes a bit spotty as no one really checked up on our table). Rating 4/5.
Final thoughts: 
Don't go out of your way to eat here. 
Decent Indian food for a cheap meal.

review.author: T F.
review.description: Dining room had good atmosphere, very prompt and attentive (bordering formal) service, and food that was fantastic. The flavors were deep and complex. The naan was fresh out of the oven and perfect. We ordered starters, mains, and desserts. All five members of our group raved about their dishes.

review.author: Cla S.
review.description:
My first night in London, we decided to stay near the action which luckily happens to be a quick ride from the flat where I'm staying. My bro suggested we have some Indian so we went into Roti Chai.
The upstairs of RC has an unassuming dining hall style space with a tapas inspired indian menu. Traditional diners can head downstairs for full waiter and menu service. We did and ordered:
Bengali fish and crab cakes - 9/10 
I couldn't differentiate between the two but both were of great consistency, dressed with wonderful colourful sauce and crunchy coated warmness. Near best fish/crab cakes ever had (two establishments in Chicago and Tanzania still hold those titles).
Schezwan chilli paneer- 8/10 
This was the other appetizer star of the night. A familiar dish but served on skewers for a change, this proved to be an excellent vegetarian option, and perfect for a mild palate.
Saagwala gosht- 9/10
Now as far as the mains were concerned, this is one for the books. I never order gosht but will have to remember it moving forward. Succulent goat meat in a green bath of herbs and yoghurt- almost the perfect 10 in my humble opinion. Could have been spicier though.
Butter chicken- 7.5/10
This was my main dish and met (but did not exceed) my expectations. Cooked beautifully, it paled in comparison to the other mains shared but no leftovers so don't be shy to order it up.
Awadhi lamb rack- 8.5/10
This was the best dish as far as presentation goes, and the lamb itself was tender and very flavourful, but its portion was a bit on the small side and it did not accompany the rice and naan as well as the curry and stew.
Garlic naan- 6/10- garlicky but could use some salt &butter. Bit flat. 
Rice- 8/10- your standard saffron rice, more dry than sticky. 
Wine- 10/10
This fabulous meal was enjoyed with a bottle of Pinot Grigio that I've also noted for future reference. 
Lastly for dessert we tried the 
chocolate mousse- 8/10. It was enjoyable. Small yet rich enough to be shared, it came with a cream sauce and was a great way to end the night, savour-wise. Wished I'd had a coffee with it for an ideal palate cleanser duo.
Overall: 4.5 but rounded up for atmosphere + service points. See pics.
I RECOMMEND- Exploring the menu! Nothing displeased us. 
EXTRA TIP-Slightly on the pricey side. We were in a celebratory (read: indulgent) mood but our bill was on the high end especially for the travelling diner (damn you ole GBP!) Stay upstairs in the street kitchen if you respect your budget ;)

review.author: Serena H.
review.description:
Chicken lollipops are amazing. And the chilli chicken burger was very good.. 
expect fusion style on the first floor, tapas style portions
Highly recommended!!

review.author: Delaney W.
review.description:
DELICIOUS Indian food! We assumed that we'd have to wait a bit for a table since we went on a Saturday night, but we only had to wait about 5 minutes. We ate in the downstairs dining room.
My husband & I shared the butter chicken, the garlic naan, the basmati rice, and the Indian cheese appetizer. The food came astonishingly fast (like, 2 minutes after ordering, no joke) - but was incredibly fresh and delicious. We ate every bite!
My husband also got the Bhai Cider with his meal and said it complemented perfectly.

review.author: Christie K.
review.description:
It's always a good sign when an Indian friend raves about an Indian restaurant.  A friend from NY was in town and thought it was a good opportunity to check out this place since it's in a central location.  My friend recommended the street kitchen over the dining room - but wish you were able to interchangeably order from both menus but anyways...
I started out with the Hakka Chili Paneer and Papri Chaat.  I really enjoyed the paneer.  I think I could just order that with a side of rice for dinner and be really content.  The papri chaat was really good - my friend says it proper punjabi!  It feels a bit on the heavier side with all the yogurt and stuff but none the less very tasty.
I had the curried chickpeas whilst my friend had the curry fish and we shared a roti basket - which had a variety of 3 different kinds of roti (stuffed, plain).  More than enough food.  
If you're missing indian snacks and don't want to go all the way out to Tooting or Southall to pick 'em up, they sell Indian snacks at the entrance - such as masala flavoured crisps!

address.streetAddress:
3 Portman Mews South
London W1H 6AY
United Kingdom

review.author: Ann A.
review.description: Good food but very spicy and it is premade and they cannot alter anything on the menu to decrease the level of heat/ spice.  One of the people in our party never got her main entree.  They never brought it

review.author: Eric S.
review.description:
This is actually two different restaurants at the same location.  I have been here three times over the last weeks. The first time, there was no seating available in the upper street-cafe area, so I went downstairs to the fairly traditional British Indian restaurant. Despite it being his first night on the job, service was good, with his mentor following-up to make certain all was done correctly.  I had a simple chicken curry and a pepper/whiskey drink.  They did not ask how spicy I wanted  the curry and it was tasty, buy no heat.  Very adequate.
On the next two occasions I sat upstairs, which is much more casual, with small-plate style menu.  My favorite dish is the warm pepper salad (sorry, I have forgotten the name) with fried Paneer.  It is wonderfully hot and flavorful. I also enjoy the "Chicken Lollipops" with mint chutney.  It is loud and boisterous.  Highly recommend the top area for a good casual meal.

review.author: Jahanbi R.
review.description: FINALLY!! Had heard about Roti Chai from friends. We sat on the Main floor, the Street Food Corner, as suggested by our friends. The chaats are the best. Had chicken lollipop and Hakka chilli paneer which were fantastic and spicy. Also had tasty Railway Lamb Curry. The cherry on the cake was the Pistachio Kulfi - creamy, refreshing and yummy! If you are bored of the usual Indian food, this place can be a good change to your taste-buds.

review.author: Steve K.
review.description: Came back to back nights. Was seated in the dining room (had reservations). Great atmosphere, great food, great cocktails. The dining room allows babies but no high chairs or strollers. The casual dining area does allow strollers, but doesn't take reservations and you'll be waiting a bit if you show up during typical dining hours.

review.author: Maddison H.
review.description:
Came here to eat the street food, but due to it being busy we had to eat downstairs in the dining room. Food was nice, but I very much doubt the 16hour lamb was cooked for 16 hours.
Staff friendly, deserts good- but, I think the Mali cheesecake was just a dense cheesecake. Overall, very good value for money. 
Would eat here again, and I look forward to trying the street food.

review.author: Meghana D.
review.description:
My friend and I had dinner here (upstairs) on a Wednesday night. To start off - the ambience is a bit harsh (too many harsh lights etc. ). 
The food itself is quite good - we had the chicken and lamb curries as mains which were quite tasty. For starters we had pani puri and papdi chat - these were a bit disappointing. Didn't have the zing that chaat is supposed to have. 
All in all - decent Indian food that isn't too greasy and isn't too expensive.

review.author: Carol L.
review.description:
There are two levels -- the Street Kitchen and Dining Room (downstairs) -- and each has a completely different menu so be sure to peruse them before deciding where you want to dine (by the way, they offer more than what the menus online indicate).  We decided on the more casual Street Kitchen.
There is a featured cocktail of the month, which was a Lychee Teapot Martini when we went in July.  We didn't order it, opting instead for:
* MAHA MOJITO - Made with ginger, mint and a rum blend, it was fine, but nothing of note. 
* KOVALAM BEACH - This one was a non-alcoholic cocktail made with ginger ale, lychee, guava and coconut.  It was pretty good, but the best one was... 
* COCONUT AND GUAVA BELLINI SHARBAT - Amazing!  Subtle, sweet and very refreshing.  We definitely had another.  It was easily the best drink we had during our entire trip to London!
There is also a seasonal special featured on the menu.  When we went they were showcasing the MANCHURIAN, a classic dish which they describe "was created by Nelson Wang in Mumbai in 1975 and involves a traditional Indian sauce made with ginger, garlic and chilis but finished with dark soy sauce rather than garam masala to create a unique flavour."  We ordered the CHICKEN MANCHURIAN.  It came with a bowl of steamed rice.  Very akin to adobo dishes I've had.  Good, but not the best thing we had.  The portions are on the small side on the street level, but are still shareable.  We also ordered:
* RAILWAY LAMB CURRY - Lamb and potatoes served with two chapatis.  Our server offered to substitute rice for the chapatis.  I declined but eventually ordered a side of rice anyhow to soak up some curry.  Yummy.  I preferred this one to the Manchurian.
* SAMOSAS - We chose the spicy pea and potato samosas.  You get two of them, plus chickpeas and dipping sauces.  A tad on the dry side but generally still a good choice.
yelp.com/user_local_phot…
* TARKA DHAL - Yellow lentils.  Delicious.  Must have rice or something to eat this with.
* CHICKEN LOLLIPOPS - This was our favorite dish!  You get five of these Moreish Keralan spiced chicken wings and a dipping sauce.  So good!  We almost (almost) ordered another, but as it was we had already over-ordered and this place is not cheap.
yelp.com/user_local_phot…
* Side of ROTI - Good by itself and topped with dhal, curry, etc.
yelp.com/user_local_phot…

review.author: Aakriti J.
review.description: Oh man literally my favorite Indian street food place in London (maybe even outside of India?!?). The food is so creative , and I love the decor and ambience of the restaurant. It's just absolutely perfect! And the spicy szichuan paneer is SO GOOD. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. I can't stop myself from going here again And again !!

review.author: Andrea D.
review.description:
It's a very good Indian restaurant, between Marble Arch and Bond Street (central line).
I tried it with 6 friends on January 2016 at dinner: excellent food and service.
Good modern atmosphere (not the traditional atmosphere of most of the restaurant for tourists).
Interesting price

review.author: Nawaf A.
review.description:
Great food and service, i love this place. 
Tried lamb and chicken biryanis and they are so good. I think it's the best indian restaurant around the area.
The orange cake is delicious

review.author: Jenn T.
review.description:
Top notch Indian food in Mayfair area. This restaurant is kind of hidden on a back street but it is well known by locals. I have not had to make a reservation when going for lunch but am unsure about dinner. There is ample room upstairs and a huge downstairs area which they probably open up for overflow.
This is a child friendly spot with high chairs and pram parking. 
Now for the food... It's AMAZING! Everything I've ordered has been delicious. My husband and I went here when I was pregnant and ordered the hot wings to try and induce labour. While it didn't work, the hotness level was intense! We both have high tolerance for spice so this was prefect for us!

review.author: Asish P.
review.description:
We were only in London for a week, and ended up eating here twice... once upstairs and once downstairs.
The concept is great... indian street food.
The decor is great... downstairs looks like the inside of a train, with the overhead compartments, etc.... and the upstairs reminds me of a market area.
Service was also great both times.
Downstairs is a more formal area, where you can make reservations.  Upstairs has a more cafe type feel to it, and does not accept reservations.
The menu is different in both spots.  Downstairs is more meals, and upstairs is more focused on snack items.  Both were great, but my preference was definitely the downstairs menu... but only marginally.  Food was excellent either way.
Downstairs, i think we ordered almost all of the appetizers.  My favorite was the shrimp, and also the kebabs.  Upstairs,  the best was the lamb burger, but we also had 10 different items.  the only thing i was disappointed in was the chicken wings.  Didn't have too much to it.... and seemed really mild and plain compared to the rest of the meal.
Love Indian food in London, and this place did not disappoint.

review.author: Vanesss S.
review.description:
Best Indian food I've ever had! 
I'm from Germany but I'm going to fly to London only for this restaurant. 
Love it!

review.author: Jerry W.
review.description: Great dinner for my wife and myself. Food was exceptional and staff was very attentive. Enjoyed our first evening visiting London.

review.author: Sarah B.
review.description: Everything my mom and I ordered was absolutely amazing and from the moment we walked in every person working was beyond kind and helpful! Our server Veronika was not only attentive, but she was also a great guide towards what to order and was incredibly kind. For dinner we had the Hakka Chili Paneer (very spicy and flavorful,) vegetable samosas (more so mild but good,) chicken samosa chaat (WOW! So decadent and yummy,) the pulusu chicken (decadent,) and last but certainly not least the duck porridge. The duck porridge was by far the favorite item and despite being full I nearly devoured the whole bowl. The duck meat is minced and is absolutely fantastic. I am not usually a duck eater, but this porridge has won me over! Definitely give it a try. For dessert we finished off our wondrous meal with a mango kulfi and a pistachio kulfi, which was the perfect end to a fantastic meal.

review.author: Faisal L.
review.description:
I have been going to Roti Chai for a couple of years, but just getting around to writing this review. It is a very authentic indian experience, without the strong smells. The main floor is indian street food (recommended), while the basement is a bit more formal (although I have never eaten there). 
My suggestion is to try out a few items family style from the vibrant and diverse menu. Everything is worth trying (bun kebab, chicken lollipops, papri chaat, railway lamb and chicken pulusu) are all unique and tasty. If you like to try a fancy drink, I suggest trying their special martini. I forget the name but its pinkish, served cold in a kettle and very obvious when you look at the menu.

review.author: Sharet B.
review.description: Amazing food! We stop by because of the Yelp reviews. Our last night in London and we got lucky with a table available downstairs. Everything was really good. Prawns appetizer TOP TOP !!!

review.author: Menaal M.
review.description: Authentic street food. Fun vibe. You'll always see a lot of desis here which is a good sign! :)

review.author: Rose L.
review.description: Excellent food. I wish they had this in nyc!  We loved the appetizer and buns and the entrees were delic!  There's so many atypical dishes that u have to come back & try again. It's definitely worthwhile. We tried fire wings, chat, and chicken bits for appetizer. Also had the chicken bun & fish curry. All delic! The masala chai was authentic.  Yummy!

review.author: Raam S.
review.description:
My wife and I walked into roti chai with a lot of high expectations because last year we were here, it was fantastic.
We were seated straightaway but it took sometime for a waiter to come and talk to us.
We ordered two masala chais. two pani puris and a fentiman's rose lemonade.
The pani puris were very good and felt very well on the palate. The pani had the correct amount of tang, sweetness and hotness to it.
The masala chai, however was a disappointment. it felt more like someone had boiled some hot water in a hurry with a tea bag and a drop of milk in it. I mean, an establishment called roti chai serves a deplorable chai and that's a bit ironic.
Nevertheless, 3 stars for a good pani puri, quick seating and decent customer service.

address.streetAddress:
3 Portman Mews South
London W1H 6AY
United Kingdom

review.author: Soo Jin M.
review.description:
The hostess definitely saved the day for us.  We had to wait a very long time, and then after being seated nobody even came by for about 10 minutes.  She noticed and came to take our orders.  She's definitely the heroine of this establishment!
We had a bun chilli chicken which was amazing!  Full of flavor and just unlike anything we've ever had.  The chicken lollipops were decent too.  Ironically, the lamb curry was the worst part of the meal.  It was not very good.  Also I wouldn't spend the money on chai tea, it wasn't anything special. 
I'd definitely come again, but just for that sandwich!  It's going to haunt my dreams!

review.author: Matt C.
review.description:
Outstanding Indian Food.
Delicious!!!
Recommended to my GF and I by the friends we were staying with...  We walked there, waited a few minutes, its casual...
Also, there are 02 restaurants here so don't get confused..  01 upstairs, 01 downstairs.
We went to the one upstairs!
Everythang was extremely yummy.
If/when back in the area I would def go again.
And definitely I recommend!!!

review.author: Mike L.
review.description: I have only eaten upstairs and not really sure if I would try the more upscale experience downstairs. If you like Indian food - you are going to find Chicken Tiki Masala here... this is Indian Street Food and so glorious! Come with friends and order a bunch of different things - you can't go wrong!

review.author: Mark L.
review.description: I have absolutely nothing to complain about. Very cool two story setup. Tapas upstairs, sit down restaurant situation downstairs. We opted for a sit down meal. Very prompt and friendly service. Varied menu options and an abundance of cocktail and wine options. The food was prepared very well. Incredibly delicious. The prices were more than reasonable. I will be returning whenever I'm in the area.

review.author: Miriam W.
review.description:
I've been to Roti Chai twice. Once for dinner downstairs with a friend and again this week upstairs for a big group dinner. I can now attest to Roti Chai's excellent food and recommend them for large parties too.
When I booked our table we were given the option of four menus, two for upstairs (street kitchen) and two for downstairs (dining room). I liked the casual feel of the street kitchen upstairs and preferred the menu there too.
Our party of ten started with the Hakka chilli paneer, tandoori chicken pao and the aloo papri chaat. 
Normally not a fan of paneer, this version was spicy (thanks to the fresh chillies), wonderful and nothing like any paneer I've sampled. I think I had thirds. 
The tandoori chicken pao might seem like some fusion creation but small bun sandwiches like these are served all over India (particularly in Mumbai where they're a ubiquitous street food). 
Whilst I thoroughly enjoyed them all, my favourite of the starters was the aloo papri chaat - a flavor explosion brought to you by chickpeas, yoghurt and chutney and something hard to find in my neck of the woods. 
Overall, I liked the starters slightly better than the mains during our dinner.
The standout among the entrees for me was the rustic Punjabi chicken curry. The new-to-the-menu duck leg was also a standout (especially its accompanying sauce).
 
For dessert almost all of us had the mango kulfi. (I mean, who doesn't love ice cream on a stick?)
 
Service was uneven at best (seems most of the staffers were on their first or second shifts) but that didn't but a damper on our meal at all. We got everything we ordered and it arrived in a mostly timely manner.
I'd definitely go back to Roti Chai with a big group.

review.author: Laurence W.
review.description:
First class Indian food - at least to my clumsy American palate - and clever spiced cocktails that tend toward the sweet side.  The duck is the clear winner here, but the starters were fine all the way around.
Service could use a refresher course, but I don't really care when the food is this good.

review.author: Sanj M.
review.description:
I went a little weak at the knees over a Roti Chai lamb bun at the Feast food fair earlier this year, so I was pretty excited to try out the actual restaurant. In case you were wondering, the name means the equivalent of Bread & Tea - but fear not, there's a lot more interesting stuff on the menu!
Step 1 - Find it: It's tucked away on a quiet street behind Bond Street tube, which reminded me I should never walk down Oxford St and ought to do more exploring around it. The ground level street kitchen of colourful Indian signs and posters is kept for walk-ins (or bookings of at least 6), so we'd booked a table for 4 in the more formal downstairs Dining Room to be on the safe side. When we arrived though there was plenty of room in the brightly buzzing Street Kitchen, and as we were after a more casual meal they were happy for us to move up (I got the feeling this happens a lot).
Step 2 - Drink: Not to be overlooked - it's an Indian restaurant that actually serves more beers than just Tiger/Cobra! Though I was having a girly girl moment and chose the most flowery thing on the menu with my friend - a rose and lychee martini for two, that arrived in a teapot with 2 baby glass tumblers. I found it a bit weak and there was a lot of ice in the pot, though the novelty cuteness factor carried it. The cartons of Frooti mango juice were also nice to see (just don't think about the mark-up). They do an ok job of the masala chai too, so end with that to aid digestion!
Step 3 - Eat: We went for the lots-of-smaller-dishes-to-share option, which is clearly the way to go here. Staples like the bhel puri and papri chaat are done well, and definitely try something in a bun (both meat and veg options got a thumbs up). Meanwhile the hakka chilli paneer was my tastebuds' fave, though the paneer-to-veg-ratio needs tweaking as I got a bowlful of spring onions back after making the mistake of offering it to others first. We ended up ordering a second round of our favourites, though it takes a while to flag down a server so do this as soon as you're running low. Overall have to say I wasn't wowed as there's a few things that could easily be better, but it was all flavoured well and quite authentic.
Step 4 - Repeat as required :)

review.author: Shayan S.
review.description:
I don't often go to Indian restaurants in London. Maybe it's because I prefer my mother's cooking. Or maybe it's because I'm almost always invariably disappointed. But not this time. After reading the reviews, decided to book this place for a friend's going away dinner.
First of all, the place looks amazing (see the pics that I posted). The ground floor has the street food menu, and has a really nice feel to it. I wouldn't say authentic, because emulating the streets of Kolkata is neigh impossible. However there is an attention to detail that makes you feel like you're travelling to another place, another destination. I didn't eat off the street food menu however, and headed straight downstairs to the main restaurant, which is tastefully decorated and a bit posher than the ground floor restaurant.
I was immediately surprised to see that they had Sam Adams Boston lager on the menu.... a first for me in anIndian restaurant. For once, I ordered that instead of the standard issue King Fisher beer.
For starters, we had the Gilafi seekh kebab, the Bengali crab and fish cake, the Chicken 65 (a variant on Indian indo-chinese food), and okra. It was all very good, although the favourites were clearly the fish cake and the chicken 65. The chicken was super crispy and perfectly cooked, and the hot sauce that it is served with is addictive! One thing that I immediately noticed was that they are not afraid to turn on the heat. The food here is definitely spicy! 
For the mains, we ordered the Saagwala gosht (lamb curry with spinach), the awadhi lamb rack, the pork belly, and for me, what was essentially the star of the evening, the Kerala duck roast. Let's talk about that duck for a second. I was very worried when I ordered it, because the menu speaks of a duck confit served with a Kerala tangy/spicy sauce. Now I know my duck confit. I make this stuff about once a month for my friends. I'm super picky about how crispy the skin should be, and how easily the meat must fall of the bone when served. Let me just say that they cooked that duck leg perfectly. And the garnish of carrots, the sauce was absolutely divine. Now this is a diwali special, and I don't know how long this dish will stay on the menu, but if you get the chance, do yourself a favour and order it.
The sides and garnishes were good, but not over the top amazing. We had the veg kulcha, and the roti, which was good, but hardened pretty quickly and was a bit too dry. The tarka dahl was good, and it was refreshing to see this served. It was spicy and had a decent amount of garlic in it!
We skipped dessert and ordered the Masala chai which was excellent. Not too sweet, and perfect balance of cardamom and sweetened condensed milk!
All in all, it came down to about 30£ per person. Won't break the bank, but don't expect a brick lane tab. This is Marylebone.
I have to agree with the other reviews about the service. It needs more attention to detail, follow up and diligence. But hey, at least it's not rude,just a bit lazy. The food makes up for this, which is why him giving them 4 stars.
I will definitely make plans to go back. Roti chai, together with Trishna (in the same vicinity), have fast become my favourite Indian restaurants in this city.

review.author: Matt V.
review.description: Really loved this place.  The paneer salad was amazing.  Shocking in a sense that it was sort of a fusion of Chinese inspiration with Indian...I could be totally wrong, but that was the take I got.  Highly recommend getting it!   The Chai was great too as was the service and the prices

review.author: Luca D.
review.description:
Conveniently located for a quick business/shopping lunch just off Oxford street, this place offers good food and good value for your money.
I only tried the upstairs "eatery" for lunch, not the downstairs area, a proper restaurant where you can try more refined/elaborated stuff. 
Upstairs you can try some typical Indian street food and some traditional mains with a creative touch. I was delighted to find one of my favourite street snacks: pani puri, that's something you don't get in restaurants. It's some spheric, hollow crackers which you fill with a deliciously seasoned "water" and then eat in one gulp.
The other stuff I tried was very good too, even if the mains were a bit "rushed" perhaps, but after all this is a quick eatery not a 3 star restaurant.
I like the interior design, sleek yet cosy, with all those colourful Indian billboards.

review.author: Nick C.
review.description: OK yet forgettable Indian. Had a couple of similar fried chicken dishes, a tiny pani puri, a fine lamb curry, and a nicely presented patri chaat. The best part of the meal was my Beaverton Neck Oil IPA from a local London brewery. I can't see myself going back here, so three stars feels about right.

review.author: Pam C.
review.description:
Very crazy and disorganized! 
The upstairs area is very informally set, and they have really cool decorations on the wall. The menus are laid out on the table when you're seated. 
If you're looking for butter chicken, this isn't the place to go! However if you're looking for a wide variety of Indian foods from across the continent then roti chai is a great place to check out. Their roti selection is pretty good - some naan, chipatis, and a couple of very good bean stuffed roti that I couldn't identify. The only paneer dish they had was ridiculously spicy in a good way - if you want spicy food it's definitely the dish to try. The trio of chutneys is also good, and their cucumber yogurt tastes cool without being too overwhelmingly yogurt-y. 
Main complaint is probably the organization. We went on a pretty busy night, and they just seemed like they were crazy understaffed. After the waiter took out order, three other waiters came and tried to take our order again. Additionally, people kept bringing things to our table that we hadn't ordered. We were also charged for still water when we ordered tap, and it took them 15 minutes to get us another order of roti. Service is quite slow if you consider that everything is premade. The staff just seemed like quite a mess, but they were gracious and quick when it came to correcting mistakes. 
Worth coming to! Pretty delicious food.

review.author: Schelly Y.
review.description:
Tucked away behind the craziness of Oxford St is Roti Chai. There are two dining options which include the street food upstairs and the more formal dining room downstairs. We opted for the dining room this time around but would love to try the upstairs.
The pork belly and chicken tikka were the best items! Super flavorful and juicy, we loved every bite. We were a bit disappointed in the small naan portions but overall it was a great meal. Excellent and fast service as well!
Pork vinha d alhos
Tarka Dhal
Malai Chicken Tikka- marinated with cardomom and black pepper 
Butter Chicken- Darya Ganj style with a touch of fenugreek
Garlic Naan

review.author: Minyoung S.
review.description:
We (Americans from Colorado) visited Roti Chai (Downstairs Dining Room) during a family trip to London (including three kids and grandparents). 
Monday night offered a fixed menu with 2-course (£19) and 3-course (£22) options. For a starter, the Malai Chicken Tikka was excellent. This is my favorite Indian dish, and they knocked it out of the park. We all agreed that we would have preferred this as our main course. There were four adults, so we shared our courses family style.
Roti Chai has two distinct dining areas, each with its own menu. The "Street Kitchen" is on the ground floor (sometimes referred to as "upstairs") and offers items such as Chicken Lollipops and Samosas, which were not available in the Downstairs Dining Room. I actually like concept, as it provides yet another reason to come back.
Also, we chose this restaurant, in part because some reviews indicated this was a good place for kids. This might be true for the Street Kitchen. However, if you have kids and are eating Downstairs: It might be worth instructing the server to bring out all of your courses at once. There was some confusion about when we were finished with our first course, and this needlessly added at least half an hour to our dining time (which can be tenuous with a five year old).
Overall, the Best Indian Food that we have ever had. The Chicken Tikka was amazing (try to get it as your main course).

review.author: Des D.
review.description:
Excellent food, we ordered a variety of dishes all of which were received with great satisfaction .  Portions slightly on the small size but not humbling small.  Cannot wait to try this one again.
Thank YELP for being spot on with 4.5 stars.

review.author: Connor B.
review.description: Good place which is perfect for dates or for larger groups - the bar had a great selection of drinks (reasonably priced) and the food was tasty.

review.author: Blaine S.
review.description: I had a good experience at this restaurant. It had a nice atmosphere and the food was good. They ran out of the beer I wanted to try and that was a small disappointment. The food was good but the menu was small. My Indian dish was a chicken curry. There was too much ginger in it and it made for a spicy but not so tasty combination.  Overall it was good and i would probably go back.

review.author: Mark S.
review.description: Had a great meal here. I definitely recommend the "Chicken lollipops", which were basically crispy deep fried chicken legs. Everything else was top notch too - you'll probably want to order a number of small dishes and eat family style. After all, sharing is caring. Certainly a good place for lunch, as it was busy but not too crazy. Probably worth booking ahead though.

review.author: Janet N.
review.description: Food is okay. The hostess needs to be a lot more organized... She kept us waiting for almost 30 minutes, and when I saw that a table had been kept open I finally inquired about it (thinking there's no way she would keep us waiting when that table is ours). As a matter of fact, she HAD forgotten about us! Space is chill and cool though.

review.author: Aviv S.
review.description:
Great in theory...poor in practice!
I should have known that something was wrong when I saw that not a single patron, server or chef was Indian. While the menu screams of the promise delivered by authentic Indian street food delights, the reality is that you end up with deep fried chicken and bland, watered down colored sauces masquerading as spices.
What is really shocking is that people pay so much money to stomach not just the poor excuse for food but the pollution and congestion around Oxford street as well.
My advice, find the place the local Indian people frequent to find real Indian food. And avoid this tourist trap like the plague!

address.streetAddress:
3 Portman Mews South
London W1H 6AY
United Kingdom

review.author: Erica U.
review.description:
Indian Street food with lovely decor throughout. 
Food was good, wish I knew what to order. I had a rice dish that was a bit unexpected,  Felt a bit like a fish out of water with the cuisine but we did the best we could. 
I would definitely try this again for a better pov. 
Service could use some work. I sat around for a total of about 40 min waiting for service to bring menus, to order drinks, to order and a long time for the check.

review.author: Anya Y.
review.description: Great dining experience!
